questiontext.text:
Differentiation of a general function from first principles

Consider the graph of \(y = f(x)\) shown in the Figure below.




Carefully make the following observations: 

(a) Point \(A\) has coordinates \( (x, f(x)) \). 

(b) Point B has coordinates \( (x + h, f(x + h)) \). 

(c) The straight line \(AB\) has gradient \[ \dfrac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \] 

(d) If we let \(h \to 0\) we can find the gradient of the graph of \(y = f(x)\) at the arbitrary point \(A\), provided we can evaluate the appropriate limit on \(h\). The resulting limit is the derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\) and is written \( \dfrac{df}{dx} \) or \(f'(x)\).



Key Point

Definition of Derivative

Given \(y = f(x)\), its derivative is defined as \[ \dfrac{df}{dx} = \dfrac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \] in the limit as \(h\) tends to \(0\). This is written \[ \dfrac{df}{dx} = \lim_{h \to 0} \dfrac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \] In a graphical context, the value of \( \dfrac{df}{dx} \) at \(A\) is equal to \( \tan \theta \) which is the tangent of the angle that the gradient line makes with the positive \(x\)-axis.

Example

Differentiate \(f(x) = x^2 + 2x + 3\) from first principles.

Solution

\begin{align} \dfrac{df}{dx} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \left\{ \dfrac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \right\} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \left\{ \dfrac{ [(x + h)^2 + 2(x+h) + 3] - [x^2 + 2x + 3]}{h} \right\} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \left\{ \dfrac{ x^2 + 2xh + h^2 + 2x + 2h + 3 - x^2 - 2x -3}{h} \right\} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \left\{ \dfrac{ 2xh + h^2 + 2h}{h} \right\} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \left\{ 2x + h + 2 \right\} \\ &= 2x + 2 \end{align}
